1. The Orphans keep coming back Orphans of the Wheat Market Price: $0.05

Savior of the Small Market Price: $0.04

This two-card combo is hard to break up in combat. Orphans of the Wheat can tap Savior of the Small and perhaps a few other creatures to build a humongous attacker. Yet even if the opponent manages to line up enough blockers, Savior of the Small's survival ability will return it right away. This will grant a big advantage in a long game.

  1. Build your own Embercleave Violent Urge Market Price: $0.05

Frantic Strength Market Price: $0.02

Duskmourn manifests horrible evils, but it will also be scary to play against a red-green deck in this format for a different reason. The opponent might attack with an inconspicuous 3/3, but if they have delirium and the right combination of cards, then it could suddenly turn into a 6/5 trampler. Frantic Strength and Violent Urge work very well together, and it's something to watch out for.

  1. More double strike value Sheltered by Ghosts Market Price: $1.39

Ticket Booth // Tunnel of Hate Market Price: $0.04

Sheltered by Ghosts can remove an opposing creature for two mana, but it can effectively take one of your creatures out of the equation as well. For example, if you put it on a vanilla 3/3, then you never want to risk it in combat, as then the opponent can just trade for it and get the exiled permanent back.

So to really make good use of it, you'll want to put it on an evasive creature or combine it with double strike effects. Double strike is a particularly good choice because it potentially doubles the effectiveness of lifelink. One way to accomplish that is with Tunnel of Hate, which gives one of your attackers double strike every turn. When you're crashing in with a 4/3 double striking lifelinker, it will be easy to win the damage race.

  1. Get slaying Fear of Being Hunted Market Price: $0.06

Most Valuable Slayer Market Price: $0.01

This is a formidable curve for red decks in this format. With turn-three Fear of Being Hunted into turn-four Most Valuable Slayer, you basically create a one-sided The Abyss. You get a 5/2 that must be blocked, and thanks to first strike, it will typically eat that blocker and live to tell the tale. If you really want to be sure, you an add Widow's Walk to give deathtouch, though that is generally not necessary.

In red-white decks, Fear of Being Hunted also works well with Ethereal Armor. Look out for these synergies to make the most of your cards.

  1. Trigger Arabella every turn Ragged Playmate Market Price: $0.03

Arabella, Abandoned Doll Market Price: $0.42

Arabella, Abandoned Doll has a powerful triggered ability in a proper red-white deck, but as a measly 1/3, it's hard to attack with her multiple times. If your opponent has a halfway decent blocker, she won't survive combat. But that's where Ragged Playmate comes in. It's not only a two-power creature to boost Arabella's triggered ability, but it can also make Arabella unblockable turn after turn. Together, they'll easily drain the opponent over time.

  1. An incredible opening salvo Optimistic Scavenger Market Price: $0.14

Grand Entryway // Elegant Rotunda Market Price: $0.05

This combination of a common and an uncommon is one of the best early-game curves available in the format. On turn one, you lead with Optimistic Scavenger. On turn two, you play Grand Entryway, creating a Glimmer. Since two enchantments enter, Optimistic Scavenger triggers twice. Then on turn three, you unlock Elegant Rotunda, getting another Optimistic Scavenger trigger.

With this curve, you can attack with a 5/5 Optimistic Scavenger and a 2/2 Glimmer on turn three, dealing seven damage to an opponent who has surely not set up adequate defenses yet.

  1. The weirdest white removal Reluctant Role Model Market Price: $0.41

Patched Plaything Market Price: $0.07

Reluctant Role Model's second ability does not say "target creature your control" - it can target any creature. So, if you control a Patched Plaything with two -1/-1 counters and it dies, then you can put the -1/-1 counters on an opponent's creature. The end result is the weirdest creature removal, but it's a strong combination to look out for.

  1. Bounce your removal spell Fear of Isolation Market Price: $0.09

Nowhere to Run Market Price: $0.60

The eerie theme of Duskmourn Limited requires a lot of enchantments, and many spot removal effects that would typically be seen on instants or sorceries have been tweaked into an enchantment form. Nowhere to Run and Glassworks are good examples of this. As a result, Fear of Isolation's bounce tax can often be an upside. Simply pick up Nowhere to Run or Glassworks, and you'll get another use out of them!

Of course, Fear of Isolation's usefulness is not limited to those enchantments. For example, when you're missing land drops, you can return a tapped land, allowing you to replay the land for a free mana. Bouncing creature generators, such as Glimmerlight or Tunnel Surveyor, can also prove useful. But the ability to double-up on one of your removal spells is surely one of the more powerful combinations to remember when drafting Duskmourn.
